article.headline: Arkansas 80, Louisiana Tech 50
article.story: FAYETTEVILLE, Ark. (AP) -- It was clear midway through the first half Arkansas was looking for a spark. They found it on the defensive end. The Razorbacks unleashed a full-court press that forced 15 first half turnovers, including a dozen in the final 10 minutes of the period that fueled an 80-50 victory over Louisiana Tech on Saturday. "Coach (Stan Heath) wants us to show intensity on the defensive end," Arkansas guard Gary Ervin said. "That leads to transition points for us." Arkansas (10-3) led just 15-13 with 11 minutes, 29 seconds left in the first half when Louisiana Tech's Marcus Elliot completed a three-point play. Heath changed the strategy and turned Sonny Weems loose. The result was a 22-8 Arkansas run as Weems and the Razorbacks forced more than 10 Bulldog turnovers. The half was punctuated by a Weems steal on the defensive end when he picked Elliot and fed Patrick Beverley. Beverley tossed the ball back to Weems, who scored to help the Razorbacks to a 37-21 lead at the break. "I was pleased with our effort," Heath said. "The intensity came from our defense. We were so active, running the floor and we didn't turn the ball over." Louisiana Tech coach Keith Richard was disappointed. "Our guards played like junior high guards against NBA guards," Richard said. The 50 points allowed was a season-best for the Razorbacks. Arkansas also was effective with its post play on the offensive end as Charles Thomas (16 points) and Darian Townes (12) combined for 28 points. Thomas has averaged 17 points per game over the past four games. Beverley scored 13 points. Arkansas had nine 3-pointers on the game and just 11 turnovers, while accumulating 19 assists led by Weems with five. For the sixth time in the last seven games, the Razorbacks had more assists than turnovers. "That has been our barometer," Heath said. "When we take care of the ball, we win." The Bulldogs (2-10) failed to solve Arkansas' zone defense. "You simply cannot score against a defensive team like Arkansas," Richard said. "Arkansas has size and gets plays because they are taller." Chad McKenzie led Louisiana Tech with 16 points.

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.
